   &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;166,667&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt; padding-left: 10pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Forfeited&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;#8212;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;#8212;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Outstanding at July 31, 2021&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;2,012,500&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;1,679,167&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Stock Option Plans&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;2007 Equity Incentive Plan&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In February 2016, we amended and restated our 2007&#13;Equity Incentive Plan, the (&amp;#8220;2007 Plan&amp;#8221;), to, among other changes, increase the number of shares of common stock issuable&#13;under the 2007 Plan by 4,000,000 shares and extend the term of the 2007 Plan until February 4, 2026. The 2007 Plan provides for the grant&#13;of incentive and non-qualified stock options, as well as other share-based payment awards, to our employees, directors, consultants and&#13;advisors. These awards have up to a 10-year contractual life and are subject to various vesting periods, as determined by the Compensation&#13;Committee of the Board of Directors. As of July 31, 2021, there were approximately 1,352,000 shares available for issuance under the 2007&#13;Plan.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;2017 Equity Incentive Plan&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In January 2021, we amended and restated our 2017&#13;Equity Incentive Plan, the (&amp;#8220;2017 Plan&amp;#8221;), to, among other changes, increase the number of shares of common stock issuable&#13;under the 2017 Plan by 5,000,000 shares and extend the term of the 2007 Plan until January 2031. The 2017 Plan provides for the grant&#13;of incentive and non-qualified stock options, as well as other share-based payment awards, to our employees, directors, consultants and&#13;advisors. These awards have up to a 10-year contractual life and are subject to various vesting periods, as determined by the Compensation&#13;Committee of the Board of Directors. As of July 31, 2021, there were approximately 3,826,000 shares available for issuance under the 2017&#13;Plan.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Stock Option Activity&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal year ended July 31, 2020, the Compensation&#13;Committee of the Board of Directors authorized the issuance of 2,550,000 stock options to our employees, officers, directors and consultants&#13;with a fair value of $946,000 as determined by the Black Scholes option pricing model. The vesting terms of the options vary between one&#13;and two years and carry a ten year term.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021, the Compensation&#13;Committee of the Board of Directors authorized the issuance of 1,555,000 stock options to our employees, officers, directors and consultants&#13;with a fair value of $471,000 as determined by the Black Scholes option pricing model. The vesting terms of the options vary between one&#13;and two years and carry a ten year term.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal year ended July 31, 2020, there&#13;was a net exercise on 440,000 stock options which resulted in the issuance of 181,998 shares of our common stock. During the fiscal year&#13;ended July 31, 2021, there was a net exercise on 624,375 stock options which resulted in the issuance of 150,190 shares of our common&#13;stock. As these options were net exercised on a cashless basis, as permitted under the respective option agreements, we did not receive&#13;any cash proceeds.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;A summary of our stock option activity for the fiscal&#13;years ended July 31, 2021 and 2020 is as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;0.76&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;6,740,375&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;5.16&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;0.83&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The weighted average expected term of options outstanding&#13;at July 31, 2020 was 6.13 years.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;For the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 share-based&#13;compensation expense for stock options vesting during the period was $758,000. For the fiscal year ended July 31, 2020 share-based compensation&#13;expense for stock options vesting during the period was $555,000.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;At July 31, 2021, options to purchase 6,740,375 shares&#13;of common stock were exercisable. These options had a weighted-average exercise price of $0.83 and a weighted average remaining contractual&#13;term of 5.16 years. The weighted average grant date fair value for options granted during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 was $0.33.&#13;The total unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested stock option grants as of July 31, 2021 was approximately $505,000 and the&#13;weighted average period over which these grants are expected to vest is 1.10 years.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We use the Black-Scholes valuation model to calculate&#13;the fair value of stock options. Share-based compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period using the straight-line method.&#13;The fair value of stock options was estimated at the grant date using the following weighted average assumptions:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="6" style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid"&gt;&#13;    &lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;For the years ended&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;    &lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;July 31,&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;2021&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 1.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 72%"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Volatility&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 11%; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;87.76&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 11%; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;83.15&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 1%"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Risk-free interest rate&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;0.92&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;0.89&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Dividend yield&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;0.0&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;0.0&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Expected life&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;5.30 years&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;5.45 years&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Volatility is the measure by which our stock price&#13;is expected to fluctuate during the expected term of an option. Volatility is derived from the historical daily change in the market price&#13;of our common stock, as we believe that historical volatility is the best indicator of future volatility.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The risk-free interest rates used in the Black-Scholes&#13;calculations are based on the prevailing U.S. Treasury yield as determined by the U.S. Federal Reserve.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We have never paid dividends on our common stock and&#13;do not anticipate paying dividends on our common stock in the foreseeable future. Accordingly, we have assumed no dividend yield for purposes&#13;of estimating the fair value of our share-based compensation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The weighted average expected life of options was&#13;estimated using the average of the contractual term and the weighted average vesting term of the options. Certain options granted to&#13;consultants are subject to variable accounting treatment and are required to be revalued until vested.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:DisclosureOfCompensationRelatedCostsShareBasedPaymentsTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;8. Related Party Transactions&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;On July 29, 2019, we entered into a Sublease Agreement&#13;(the &amp;#8220;Sublease&amp;#8221;) with SwabPlus L.P. (&amp;#8220;SwabPlus&amp;#8221;), effective July 25, 2019, pursuant to which we subleased certain&#13;office and industrial space for our corporate headquarters. The premises are located in Rancho Cucamonga, California. In December 2020,&#13;the Sublease expired. The Company is currently negotiating a new lease agreement with SwabPlus. Rent expense, including common area maintenance&#13;and real property taxes, was $87,000 and $37,000 for the years ended July 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. Tom Y. Lee, the Company&amp;#8217;s&#13;Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board and President, also serves as chairman of the board of directors and chief executive officer&#13;of SwabPlus. Mr. Lee also serves as president of Hermosa Property, Inc., the landlord of the premises subject to the Sublease. The Sublease&#13;was considered by the Company in accordance with the Company&amp;#8217;s Related Party Transaction and Procedures Policy, and approved by&#13;the disinterested members of the Board.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal year ended July 31, 2020, we sold&#13;$124,000 of product to Harmony Bioscience, Inc. PURE Chairman and CEO Tom Y. Lee is an affiliate of Harmony Bioscience.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;As of July 31, 2021 and July 31, 2020, accounts payable&#13;include $134,000 and $60,000 in board fees due to officers and directors, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Basis of Presentation&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The accompanying consolidated financial statements&#13;include the consolidated accounts of PURE Bioscience, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiary, ETIH2O Inc., a Nevada corporation. ETIH2O&#13;Inc. has no business and no material assets or liabilities and there have been no significant transactions related to ETIH2O Inc. during&#13;the periods presented in the consolidated financial statements. All inter-company balances and transactions have been eliminated.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:RevenueFromContractWithCustomerPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Revenue Recognition&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Effective August 1, 2018, we adopted the Financial&#13;Accounting Standards Board (&amp;#8220;FASB&amp;#8221;) Accounting Standards Codification (&amp;#8220;ASC&amp;#8221;), Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts&#13;with Customers (&amp;#8220;Topic 606&amp;#8221;). Under Topic 606, revenue is recognized at an amount that reflects the consideration to which&#13;we expect to be entitled in exchange for transferring goods or services to a customer. This principle is applied using the following 5-step&#13;process:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;1.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Identify the contract with the customer&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;2.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Identify the performance obligations in the contract&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;3.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Determine the transaction price&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;4.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Allocate the transaction price to the performance obligations in the contract&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;5.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Recognize revenue when (or as) each performance obligation is satisfied&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Under Topic 606, we recognize revenue when we satisfy&#13;a performance obligation by transferring control of the promised goods or services to our customers, in an amount that reflects the consideration&#13;we expect to be entitled to in exchange for those goods or services.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Our technology platform is based on patented stabilized&#13;ionic silver, and our initial products contain silver dihydrogen citrate, or SDC. SDC is a broad-spectrum, non-toxic antimicrobial agent,&#13;which offers 24-hour residual protection and formulates well with other compounds. We sell various configurations and dilutions of SDC&#13;direct to customers and through distributors. We currently offer PURE&lt;sup&gt;&amp;#174;&lt;/sup&gt; Hard Surface as a food contact surface sanitizer&#13;and disinfectant to restaurant chains, food processors and food transportation companies. We also offer PURE Control&lt;sup&gt;&amp;#174;&lt;/sup&gt;&#13;as a direct food contact processing aid.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Contract terms for unit price, quantity, shipping&#13;and payment are governed by sales agreements and purchase orders which we consider to be a customer&amp;#8217;s contract in all cases. The&#13;unit price is considered the observable stand-alone selling price for the arrangements. Any promotional or sales discounts are applied&#13;evenly to the units sold for purposes of calculating standalone selling price.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Product sales generally consist of a single performance&#13;obligation that we satisfy at a point in time. We recognize product revenue when the following events have occurred: (a) we have transferred&#13;physical possession of the products, (b) we have a present right to payment, (c) the customer has legal title to the products, and (d)&#13;the customer bears significant risks and rewards of ownership of the products.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Our direct customer and distributor sales are invoiced&#13;based on received purchase orders. Our payment terms on invoiced direct customer and distributor sales range between 30 and 90 days after&#13;we satisfy our performance obligation. The majority of our customers are on 30 day payment terms. We currently offer no right of return&#13;on invoiced sales and maintain no allowance for sales returns.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Shipping and handling are treated as activities to&#13;fulfill promises to customers and any amounts billed to a customer, if applicable, represent revenues earned for the goods provided. Costs&#13;related to such shipping and handling billings are classified as cost of sales.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We do not have significant categories of revenue that&#13;may impact how the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows are affected by economic factors.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Variable Consideration&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We record revenue from customers in an amount that&#13;reflects the transaction price we expect to be entitled to after transferring control of those goods or services. From time to time,&#13;we offer sales promotions on our products such as discounts. Variable consideration is estimated at contract inception only to the extent&#13;that it is probable that a significant reversal of revenue will not occur.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:RevenueFromContractWithCustomerPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:UseOfEstimates contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The preparation of consolidated financial statements&#13;in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, or GAAP, requires management to make estimates&#13;and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements, and the disclosures made in the accompanying&#13;notes to the consolidated financial statements. Actual results could differ materially from those estimates. Those estimates and assumptions&#13;include estimates for reserves of uncollectible accounts, inventory obsolescence, depreciable lives of property and equipment, analysis&#13;of impairments of recorded long-term tangible and intangible assets, realization of deferred tax assets, accruals for potential liabilities&#13;and assumptions made in valuing stock instruments issued for services.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:UseOfEstimates>
    <us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Cash and Cash Equivalents&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash and highly&#13;liquid investments with original maturities from the purchase date of three months or less.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsRestrictedCashAndCashEquivalentsPolicy contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Restricted Cash&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company is required to maintain $75,000 in a restricted&#13;certificate of deposit account in order to fully collateralize four revolving credit card accounts.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsRestrictedCashAndCashEquivalentsPolicy>
    <us-gaap:TradeAndOtherAccountsReceivablePolicy contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Accounts Receivable&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Trade accounts receivable are recorded net of allowances&#13;for doubtful accounts. We evaluate the collectability of our trade accounts receivable based on a number of factors. In circumstances&#13;where we becomes aware of a specific customer&amp;#8217;s inability to meet its financial obligations to the Company, a specific reserve for&#13;bad debts is estimated and recorded, which reduces the recognized receivable to the estimated amount the Company believes will ultimately&#13;be collected. In addition to specific customer identification of potential bad debts, bad debt charges are recorded based on our historical&#13;losses and an overall assessment of past due trade accounts receivable outstanding. The allowance for doubtful accounts was zero at July&#13;31, 2021 and 2020.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:TradeAndOtherAccountsReceivablePolicy>
    <us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Property, Plant and Equipment&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost less&#13;accumulated depreciation. Depreciation is computed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets. The estimated&#13;useful lives of our property, plant, and equipment range from three to ten years. Capitalized costs associated with leasehold improvements&#13;are depreciated over the lesser of the useful life of the asset or the remaining life of the lease. Depreciation is generally included&#13;in selling, general and administrative expense. Depreciation related to manufacturing is systematically allocated to inventory produced,&#13;and expensed through cost of goods sold at the time inventory is sold.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Management assesses the carrying value of property&#13;and equipment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable. If there is indication&#13;of impairment, management prepares an estimate of future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset and its eventual disposition.&#13;If these cash flows are less than the carrying amount of the asset, an impairment loss is recognized to write down the asset to its estimated&#13;fair value. For the years ended July 31, 2021 and 2020, Company Management determined there were no indicators of impairment of its property&#13;and equipment.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:IntangibleAssetsFiniteLivedPolicy contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Patents&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We have filed a number of patent applications with&#13;the United States Patent and Trademark Office and in foreign countries. Certain legal and related costs incurred in connection with pending&#13;patent applications have been capitalized. Costs related to successful patent applications are amortized over the lesser of the remaining&#13;useful life of the related technology or the remaining patent life, commencing on the date the patent is issued. Capitalized costs related&#13;to patent applications are expensed in the period in which a determination is made not to pursue such applications.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IntangibleAssetsFiniteLivedPolicy>
    <us-gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsIncludingIntangibleAssetsPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In accordance with GAAP, if indicators of impairment&#13;exist, we assess the recoverability of the affected long-lived assets, including our capitalized patent costs, by determining whether&#13;the carrying value of such assets can be recovered through undiscounted future operating cash flows. If impairment is indicated, we measure&#13;the amount of such impairment by comparing the carrying value of the asset to the fair value of the asset and we record the impairment&#13;as a reduction in the carrying value of the related asset and a charge to operating results. Estimating the undiscounted future cash flows&#13;associated with long-lived assets requires judgment, and assumptions could differ materially from actual results. There were no patent&#13;impairments during the years ended July 31, 2021 or 2020.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsIncludingIntangibleAssetsPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <PURE:ShippingAndHandlingCostsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Shipping and Handling Costs&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Shipping and handling costs incurred by us for product&#13;shipments are included in cost of goods sold.&lt;/p&gt;</PURE:ShippingAndHandlingCostsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ResearchAndDevelopmentExpensePolicy contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Research and Development Costs&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Research and development costs are expensed as incurred.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ResearchAndDevelopmentExpensePolicy>
    <us-gaap:ShareBasedCompensationOptionAndIncentivePlansPolicy contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Share-Based Compensation&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We periodically issue stock options and restricted&#13;stock awards to employees and non-employees in non-capital raising transactions for services and for financing costs. We account for such&#13;grants issued and vesting to employees based on ASC 718, whereby the value of the award is measured on the date of grant and recognized&#13;as compensation expense on the straight-line basis over the vesting period.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We estimate the fair value of share-based payment&#13;awards at the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option valuation model. The Black-Scholes option valuation model requires the input&#13;of subjective assumptions, including price volatility of the underlying stock, risk-free interest rate, dividend yield, and expected life&#13;of the option. Share-based compensation expense is based on awards ultimately expected to vest, and therefore is reduced by expected forfeitures.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ShareBasedCompensationOptionAndIncentivePlansPolicy>
    <us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Fair Value Measurements&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company determines the fair value of its assets&#13;and liabilities based on the exchange price in U.S. dollars that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit&#13;price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants on&#13;the measurement date. Valuation techniques used to measure fair value maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable&#13;inputs. The Company uses a fair value hierarchy with three levels of inputs, of which the first two are considered observable and the&#13;last unobservable, to measure fair value:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;#9679;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Level 1 &amp;#8212; Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;#9679;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Level 2 &amp;#8212; Inputs, other than Level 1, that are observable, either directly or indirectly, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;#9679;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;Level 3 &amp;#8212; Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;  &lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The carrying amounts of financial instruments such&#13;as cash, accounts receivable, inventories, accounts payable and accrued liabilities, approximate the related fair values due to the short-term&#13;maturities of these instruments.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Concentrations&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Gross sales&lt;/i&gt;. For the year ended July 31, 2021,&#13;one individual customer accounted for 11% of our net product sales. No other individual customer accounted for 10% or more of our net&#13;product sales. The geographic breakdown of net product sales was as follows: 100% U.S. For the year ended July 31, 2020, three individual&#13;customers accounted for 16%, 13% and 11% of our net product sales. No other individual customer accounted for 10% or more of our net product&#13;sales. The geographic breakdown of net product sales was as follows: 98% U.S. and 2% foreign.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Accounts receivable. &lt;/i&gt;As of July 31, 2021, we&#13;had accounts receivable from three customers that comprised 17%, 15% and 10% of total accounts receivable, respectively. As of July 31,&#13;2020, we had accounts receivable from three customers that comprised 21%, 16% and 11% of total accounts receivable, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Purchases. &lt;/i&gt;For the fiscal year ended July 31,&#13;2021, one vendor accounted for 36% of our purchases. For the fiscal year ended July 31, 2020, one vendor accounted for 54% of our purchases.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Accounts payable.&lt;/i&gt; As of July 31, 2021, one&#13;vendor accounted for 50% of the total trade accounts payable. As of July 31, 2020, one vendor accounted for 66% of the total trade accounts&#13;payable.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk>
    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We recognize deferred tax assets and liabilities for&#13;temporary differences between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and the amounts at which they are carried in the financial statements&#13;based upon the enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse. A valuation allowance is established&#13;to reduce deferred tax assets to the amount expected to be realized.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Income (Loss) Per Share&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Basic earnings (loss) per share is computed by dividing&#13;net income (loss) attributable to common stockholders by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the period. Diluted&#13;earnings per share is computed by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the sum of the weighted-average number of&#13;common shares outstanding during the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common share equivalents outstanding during the&#13;period, using the treasury stock method. Dilutive common share equivalents are comprised of in-the-money stock options and restricted&#13;stock units, based on the average stock price for each period using the treasury stock method. Since we incurred a loss for the fiscal&#13;year ended July 31, 2021 the number of shares issuable upon the exercise of stock options, the vesting of restricted stock units, and&#13;the exercise of warrants, none of which are included in the computation of basic net loss per common share, was 10,984,390. For the fiscal&#13;year ended July 31, 2020, the incremental dilutive common share equivalents were 2,402,335.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:SegmentReportingPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Segments&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;We operates in one segment for the manufacture and&#13;distribution of our products. In accordance with the &amp;#8220;Segment Reporting&amp;#8221; Topic of the ASC, our chief operating decision maker&#13;has been identified as the Chief Executive Officer and President, who reviews operating results to make decisions about allocating resources&#13;and assessing performance for the entire Company. Existing guidance, which is based on a management approach to segment reporting, establishes&#13;requirements to report selected segment information quarterly and to report annually entity-wide disclosures about products and services,&#13;major customers, and the countries in which the entity holds material assets and reports revenue. All material operating units qualify&#13;for aggregation under &amp;#8220;Segment Reporting&amp;#8221; due to their similar customer base and similarities in: economic characteristics;&#13;nature of products and services; and procurement, manufacturing and distribution processes. Since the Company operates in one segment,&#13;all financial information required by &amp;#8220;Segment Reporting&amp;#8221; can be found in the accompanying financial statements&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:SegmentReportingPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Recent Accounting Pronouncements&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-13, Credit&#13;Losses - Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments (&amp;#8220;ASC 326&amp;#8221;). The standard significantly changes how entities&#13;will measure credit losses for most financial assets, including accounts and notes receivables. The standard will replace today&amp;#8217;s&#13;&amp;#8220;incurred loss&amp;#8221; approach with an &amp;#8220;expected loss&amp;#8221; model , under which companies will recognize allowances based&#13;on expected rather than incurred losses. Entities will apply the standard&amp;#8217;s provisions as a cumulative-effect adjustment to retained&#13;earnings as of the beginning of the first reporting period in which the guidance is effective. As small business filer, the standard will&#13;be effective for us for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2022. The Company is currently assessing the&#13;impact of adopting this standard on the Company&amp;#8217;s financial statements and related disclosures.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In August 2020, the FASB issued ASU No. 2020-06 (&amp;#8220;ASU&#13;2020-06&amp;#8221;) &amp;#8220;Debt&amp;#8212;Debt with Conversion and Other Options (Subtopic 470-20) and Derivatives and Hedging&amp;#8212;Contracts&#13;in Entity&amp;#8217;s Own Equity (Subtopic 815-40): Accounting for Convertible Instruments and Contracts in an Entity&amp;#8217;s Own Equity.&amp;#8221;&#13;ASU 2020-06 will simplify the accounting for convertible instruments by reducing the number of accounting models for convertible debt&#13;instruments and convertible preferred stock. Limiting the accounting models will result in fewer embedded conversion features being separately&#13;recognized from the host contract as compared with current GAAP. Convertible instruments that continue to be subject to separation models&#13;are (1) those with embedded conversion features that are not clearly and closely related to the host contract, that meet the definition&#13;of a derivative, and that do not qualify for a scope exception from derivative accounting and (2) convertible debt instruments issued&#13;with substantial premiums for which the premiums are recorded as paid-in capital. ASU 2020-06 also amends the guidance for the derivatives&#13;scope exception for contracts in an entity&amp;#8217;s own equity to reduce form-over-substance-based accounting conclusions. ASU 2020-06&#13;will be effective January 1, 2024, for the Company. Early adoption is permitted, but no earlier than January 1, 2021, including interim&#13;periods within that year. Management is currently evaluating the effect of the adoption of ASU 2020-06 on the consolidated financial statements,&#13;but currently does not believe ASU 2020-06 will have a significant impact on the Company&amp;#8217;s accounting.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Recent accounting pronouncements issued by the FASB,&#13;including its Emerging Issues Task Force, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and the Securities and Exchange Commission&#13;did not or are not believed by management to have a material impact on the Company&amp;#8217;s present or future consolidated financial statement&#13;presentation or disclosures.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock>

    <us-gaap:ScheduleOfStockholdersEquityNoteWarrantsOrRightsTextBlock contextRef="From2020-08-01to2021-07-31">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;A summary of our warrant activity and related data&#13;is as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13; margin: 0; text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 11pt Calibri, Helvetica, Sans-Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;b&gt;July 31,&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;
